reviewText:
Evil Genius is a base-building strategy game, similar to Dungeon Keeper.

You play as a malevolent mastermind during the cold-war era, with the sole aim of taking over the world.

As with all plotting masterminds circa 1970, you have a secret base built within a mountain on a tropical island, and of course, what evil genius is complete without his evil henchmen? These fellas are under your total command and do all dirty work you task them with. You start off by hiring basic henchmen, which carry out menial tasks such as construction or basic room staffing. These henchmen then branch into three different paths: military; science; and social. These paths each have four henchmen types each, ranging from basic guards, to valets, and mad scientists.

Henchmen aren't the only things you'll find in your evil lair. There's a variety of room types to be constructed, from barracks for the men to sleep, or security rooms to manage CCTV cameras and hold prisoners. Your base requires power, and your staff have many stats (needs) that must be met. By building each type of room you can meet the demands of your ever growing lair. As you progress, more rooms and various objects for rooms can be researched via your science minions, allowing more depth to your base as well as better ways to meet the ever growing needs of your minions.

Finally, no evil lair is complete without traps. Throughout your campaign for world dominance, you're bound to draw the attention of various justice forces. From agents who snoop for incriminating evidence, to burglars trying to steal back ill-gotten gains, building traps can have all kinds of nasty effects on intruding spies. From simple pressure pads and toxic gas, to wind corridors of death, the game offers a wide selection of traps with endless customisation for you to build the ultimate defence against intruders.

Outside of your lair, hotels can be built on your island. Pesky tourists want to visit, and in order to keep them busy these establishments can be constructed to help prevent them wandering into your base. Social minions such as valets will man your hotels, and ensure tourists remain outside the base. Hotels can have a variety of recreational objects for tourists to pass time.

Away from your island is the rest of the world. Accessed via the world map, you can deploy your henchmen all over the world to perform multiple nefarious acts. From stealing money, to plotting schemes. Henchmen can also be deployed on missions in each region to build notoriety, as well as steal priceless artifacts, or even research that can be used for new objects and rooms.

The game itself, in the spirit of most similar British games made in its time, has a strong sense of humour. These moments show in the little things, such as your evil genius gloating over agents locked in your prison cells, or torture scenes consisting of the torturer smoking a cigarette, whilst the unfortunate agent being interrogated begs for a puff.

Visually, the game has aged amazingly well. Though the game was released in 2004, the clean and sleek aesthetic has allowed the game to remain as beautiful as it was at release. A rare accomplishment for many older games. Evil Genius visually competes with a lot of games released today.

Overall, if you're looking for a base-building game, look no further than Evil Genius. This game is both incredibly fun and absolutely stunning, whilst having plenty of depth and an amazing sense of humour. The game only offers a campaign mode, but will easily keep you playing for around 50 hours or more. If you find yourself wanting more, there are sandbox mods available for you to just freely build the ultimate evil lair.

A brilliant game, even by today's standards, and one of the best PC games to have ever been released.

My apologies for the story. Moving onto the game, you are tasked with the objective of constructing a hidden lair somewhere on some unknown island (where bumbling tourists and slightly less bumbling secret agents happen to wander to) with the intent of world domination. You must start smaller, however, and your options slowly unfold for you as you progress. It's pretty much Dungeon Keeper in a Bond movie setting. Over time you will research new rooms and equipment to further your schemes. Unfortunately, over time your enemies will become much less forgiving as well. You will eventually have to build a front, an island hotel to lure tourists in until they grow bored and leave. You will have to capture skilled individuals to train specialized minions. But most importantly, you will carry out evil deeds from your control center.

This brings us to the world domination portion of the game. This is basically a view of the globe on which you will place minion pieces used for stealing cash for your lair, plotting new heists and whatnot, and carrying out said shenanigans. These plots range from stealing the Eifel Tower to clubbing seals and to obliterating the city of Nashville, Tennessee, thus eliminating country music from the world; your singular act of goodwill throughout the course of the game. It's bursting with humor, much of it slapstick or parodic of spy fiction in general. If that's not your thing, you may not enjoy the game so much, but me? I can't get enough of it. reviewText:
Evil Genius is essentially a strategy/management game, where you take the role of the titular genius, in his or her bid to spread their infamy around the world. The game itself takes place almost exclusively on a tropical island that is home to your evil lair. It won't build itself though; the building and improvement of your lair is the main focus of the game.

The other main game element is the World Domination screen. The means, by which you actually make a name for yourself, collect resources and find new Henchmen.

Henchmen are your specialist minions. They don't get involved in all the daily operations in your base, but instead are directly controllable and can be used to dispatch the forces of justice or can be sent around the world to help with any stealing or plotting currently going on.

Throughout the game, tutorial videos become available to you, relating to both the world domination map and base operations. These are useful and certainly point you in the right direction.

Anyone who enjoys constant challenge will find much to love in Evil Genius. The majority of the game's features function extremely well and the theme is rock-solid throughout.

THE GOOD

+ Amazing sense of humor, style, and polish
+ Textures, filters, shading, and colors are used amazingly well
+ Sound effects, garbled speech, radio broadcasts and so on are wonderful

THE BAD

- The gameplay is a bit too slow

reviewText:
Evil Genius is a resource management game, similar to Dungeon Keeper (as many have already mentioned).

While the game is a bit old, and some of the controls, graphics, and mechanics are dated, the game is still pretty fun to play.

You have a limited amount of space to build your evil lair, room by room, on a grid system. You can send agents around the world to sabotage, steal, kidnap, and make you money, all of which help you reach your main goal of world domination.

Meanwhile you have to keep your Evil Genius safe in his lair by keeping snooping special-agents out of your base with traps and guards, and by distracting them with a fake hotel front.

The game is a little short, and there are only 3 maps, but I still do recommend the game. Whatever shortfalls the game has are madeup by the gameplay, silly humor, and style.

reviewText:
Take the base building mechanics of Dungeon Keeper with the overworld map of X-com and set it all to a parody of the James Bond universe and you've got Evil Genius.

In Evil Genius you play as an arch villian bent on world domination. You start out with a deserted island and a handful of hilariously inept workmen. As you build your base, steal money, hijack national treasures, kidnap specialists, and train your forces you'll move up the ladder of infamy.

As you become more notorious the forces of Good will grow increasingly aggressive. Expect the initial annoyance of investigators and burglars to give way to invasions by sabotuers, soldiers, and even super heroes.

Evil Genius is an easy recommendation to anyone who enjoys the dungeon building simulations ala Dungeon Keeper, or who likes the theme and setting of James Bond and doesn't mind a game that pokes fun at its foibles.

Evil Genius is a game that ask the question: Do you want to be a Bond villain? Do you want to be the guy that steals an oil tanker, not for profits, but to dump it in a wildlife reserve. Do you want to be a true mustache twirling villain.

The game is a Dungeon Keeper clone, letting you build your lair, improving the various rooms and attracting and upgrading your minions. You only have direct control of your #1 henchman the rest of your minions working on their with you giving them overall objectives to complete.

Graphically it does for the same cartoonish look as Dungeon Keeper and it works quite well. The humor is great but often put too much in the background.

Evil Genius is a great game but marred by some unfortunate mistakes. Much of the minion management quickly becomes a grind and the difficulty jumps quite a bit once super-spies appears.

Definitely worth a buy from anyone that enjoys management games and/or mustache twirling.

reviewText:
All of my reviews are based around my personnal opinion, they're not swayed by a majority of people liking or disliking it.

Better than  Prison Architect

Worse than  Dungeon Keeper 2 [www.gog.com]

NOTE:
Steam for some reason, hasn't included my entire playtime. My actual playtime is roughly around 6-7 hours.

NOTE:
All of my reviews are laid out in a particular format that fits the game.

TL:DR
Evil Genius was a hard one to review, but alas, I've finally done it, and I can say that I'm quite impressed. I first played this a couple of years ago but didn't really like it back then. I thought, since its sitting in my library, I'll give it another go. It has turned out a lot better than I thought it would. You play as an evil mastermind, tasked at building your own base and gaining noteriety around the globe by completing devious missions. Basically being a James Bond villian. If base building is your thing then yes I would recommend this!

About
Evil Genius is a base building game, where you play as one of three different evil masterminds and attain noteriety across the globe by completing missions. If you've played games like Dungeon Keeper, this will be very familiar to you. You are first placed on an island, with a few tasks to complete. You are also given a huge mountain. This is where you build your base. You are given a selection of rooms to begin with plus gaining more the more tasks you complete. Pretty much simple right?

Gameplay
Obviously, for the kind of game it is, your camera is set from above so you can manage your base easily. The game isn't as simple as it seems. Plenty of things can happen at any given time such as blackouts, attacks, e.t.c. The game gives you tutorials on how to do things when they're needed so in some ways the game does hold your hand. As I mentioned before, there are three different leaders to choose from, all of which, are different in their own ways. But no matter which one, you always start on the same island. People who are familiar to these kind of games will find it easy. Newcomers won't find it hard to adapt.

Design/Graphics
Being a game from 2004, the graphics, of course, are a little bit outdated, but that didn't bother me at all, and it shouldn't bother you. Everything is clear to understand, and there're different graphics options to fit your PC, some of which might make the game look better for you anyway. As of the design, I can say that the island you start on is a bit plain in terms of detail, but that doesn't really matter since you're trying to build a base anyway. The rooms are interesting and can have added detail anyway. It's one of those games that doesn't try to be lazy when making it.

UI [User Interface]
Again, for people unfamiliar to these kind of games, they might struggle on where to find things. Like I said earlier, there are tutorials on how to do things, but not everything. Sometimes the game leaves you to try and find out where things are and what they do. At some points I did struggle on finding my way through things, but again, you adapt. In terms of settings though, I never had a problem, nor should other people.

Pros - Interesting James Bond feel
- Unique Idea
- Plenty of entertainment
- Sinister soundtrack :D
- The game is quite humorous at times.

Cons - Can be confusing at times
- Sometimes left at points where you have no idea what to do

Final Recommendation
Evil Genius is one of those games that doesn't look amazing, but when actually played, suprises you. The idea of the game is what intruiged me the most. Playing as an evil mastermind that made you feel like a villain of James Bond is excellent in my opinion. Although sometimes confusing, Evil Genius makes up for it with It's excellent features and the enjoyment of annoying other countries. :D Worth buying if you like these kind of games, or want to get into them.

Final Verdict - 8/10.

reviewText:
Evil Genius is what happens when you have Austin Powers and Dungeon Keeper make a baby. Traps, minions, henchment, and a secret island base are all meticulously run by your Evil Genius. You defend yourself against the ever increasing interest from world governments trying to shut you down to each region's top secret spy.

But what good is a top secret spy if you just shoot him? No, there's protocol. You gloat, you find his weakness, you cheat, you scheme, you start the unneccesarily slow dipping mechanism.

At it's core Evil Genius is Dungeon Keeper with a more simple RPG aspect and a wonderfully done 1970's coat of paint. You don't control minions directly, and instead give orders to build, buy, or work through various influences. While a little buggy, and sadly only supporting 4:3 resolutions, the game still does remarkably well if you're a fan of this type of gameplay.

It's definately a rare (be it unpolished) gem that has sadly been ignored by a the general public.

A fun, funny, and challenging game with plenty of gameplay elements to keep you occupied Evil Genius is a unique simulator. Taking control of this genius and his minions is fun but challenging. Players must keep in mind that while they are trying to opperate their base, minions will do their own thing. Your sort of at the mercy of these guys in some cases. This is where you might find a little flaw in the game. Sometimes minions won't do things as fast as you want or react to an intruder unless you tag or notify them. I had a tourist end up in my freezer. This guy walked right past a hallway full of minions and ended up in the freezer. Not to mention as I was locking the tourist up, investigators came in and started taking pictures. So be prepared for incompetence from minions. However, it does add to the challenge so I wouldn't completely call this a problem.

While I'm technically still new to this game, I will say this game keeps me well entertained. From building to managing my minions on the world map, there's so much to do. Placing traps is also quite fun. Just make sure you get traps placed at the main entrance early. This may save you from having idiots trapped in your freezer. Just don't go too willy nilly on things you may not need right away. I had to start over after I accidentally wasted money on stuff I didn't need at that moment. Also, pay VERY close attention to how you use and distribute your minions. This is a crucial resource for making your lair run as smooth as possible. Keep this in mind when senting minions out into the world to do your bidding.

Overall, This game is simple and just challenging enough that you will not get bored with it.

reviewText:
To say that this is like a slightly more in depth Dungeon Keeper with a Bond Villain-esque type setting would be a very lazy to describe this. But it would be true nonetheless.

That's not a bad thing by the way. If you like that sort of thing then you'll probably get sucked into this as much as I did and  while I think I am now 'done' with it I did get plenty hours of fun.

It's good. Not perfect. But good.

The core of the game is base building and minion management and that all plays out in a similar manner to how you would expect if you've played a game like this before but where it differentiates itself a bit from the mechanics of Dungeon Keeper is that aswell as having enemies trying to break into your base and take you down you can also send out your minions into the world on missions and whatnot. Sending them on missions will earn you income, blueprints or new special henchmen and they kind of work like a modern Facebook game might in that you send people on a mission and then you just wait 5/10/15 minutes or whatever it takes untill it's done and you get a mission report. This aspect of the game can be a little annoying as time gating is rarely fun but there's always plenty of stuff to do around the base while these are happening, or you can always just make a sandwich or something. It's ok. And no microtransactions obviously.

The ai of your minions can sometimes be a bit dodgy aswell, but the game's 12 years old at the time of this review and frankly the ai can be a little bit dodgy at times even in modern releases like Prison Architect for example. So again. Like before.

It's good. Not perfect. But good

Fans of this sort of game will more than likely have an enjoyable time for X amount of hours

Evil genius puts you in the position of the leader of an emerging evil organisation - an Evil Genius. You start with money and basic rooms to start your fledgling base, and will gradually gain access to more rooms and minions as you carry out missions.

Pros -

- The game is relatively easy to learn, with a quick tutorial to show you the basics, as well as a detailed glossary for every room and item.
- The game is challenging enough to almost always keep you occurpied and thinking.
- There is quite a bit of detail in the game, especially in minion animation and such.
- Agent AI is acceptable, with them snooping around your entire base, unless you stop them with traps.
- The game visual and audio assets are quite nice. The terrain is quite low-res and undetailed, but the models look colourful. Audio is also acceptable. Overall, aesthetically, pretty good for 2004.

Cons -
- The game is very slow, and requires you to play for hours if you want to complete it. This is nice for some people, but boring for others, and you can sometimes be waiting for minutes to get funds so you can build something. There is also no time speed setting.
- Although the game has enough features to make it fun, I feel that there could be more. There are only two ways of making money - The world domination screen, where you send out minions to provinces and tell them to steal, and stealing from tourists (something I haven't been able to figure out yet).
- Pathfinding for the minions is mediocre. You will often find groups of 3 or 4 just standing by a door for a few seconds before continuing on their way.
- Revising your base design to fit new rooms closer ot the entrace, for example, can be difficult. For a new player, who doesn't know what rooms they will get later may fill up any space, then have to destroy rooms/make rooms smaller etc. The problem is that building/removing/destroying rooms and objects takes time, which can be detrimental if your base is crawling with enemy agents.

Despite the cons, I still find this game enjoyable.

reviewText:
This game is a pretty solid buy when it's on sale, I would only recommend it on sale though because it's one of those games that everything that it does right seems to have another part of the game where it goes wrong.

Pros:
Great oldies action theme. The decore and technology all look like something from that era.
Interesting progression system requiring you to complete acts of infamy.
Easy to mod. Just unpack files and change values.
Handful of unique henchman that you can directly control and have special abilities.
A nice comedic take on some things. Interogations involves smashing their heads between symbols and spinning them in an office chair so it's not gruesome. Minions will stupidly work themselves into a coma, and if low enough on stats will even walk into your bases traps.
You can kill your minions to motivate the rest of them. Pretty wicked.
A good variety of rooms and limited space makes planning a good idea.

Cons:
Basically needs to be modded or it's painful to play on many levels.

Only 3 evil geniuses, and the wiki says maximilians passive bonus to research was never even added.

Bodies of agents you kill take forever to rot and drain your minions loyalty as they sit there, you can store them in the freezer to stop it but space is limited and they take twice as long to decay in there.

Constant assualt from agents of justice constantly destroying your stuff, breaking your doors down, and robbing you. You end up having to kill them which leads right into the body bag issue and increases your head sending more agents.

The biggest rip off ever, you make extra security doors, and put traps around your base and agents just climb up through the ♥♥♥♥ing floor. One of the agents in my game crawled up in an in-accessable area of the room because there were gold bars blocking the path so she'd just shoot at people walking buy.

Money gain is a pain in the ♥♥♥ and painfully slow, you have to stick minions in the world map to steal funds but as they're there they get picked off by the local law enforcement and you only get the rewards for your efforts every 2 minutes or something like that.


Basically the game has a great premise, I'd like to see it done with a bit more to it. I modded my game to make it more playable. Made money from world map collect every 20 seconds instead of 2 minutes (still takes quite a while since your agents will get wrecked by the local police). I made it so bodies increased loyalty instead of decreasing it so they actually seem like EVIL minions and not random people who took the first job they could get. I made the freezer increase decay rates so I wouldn't have mounds of bodies piling up.

Do you remember Dungeon Keeper? You know, before EA f#cking made a sh#tty phone version, KILLED IT FOR GOOD, AND THREW THE CORPSE INTO A MOTHERF#CKING GRINDER, TO THEN SERVE YOU IT'S ORGANS ON A PIZZA? Well, games like that still exist. And this one is a great example, mixing most of the good stuff from Dungeon Keeper to (I sh#t you not) the Austin Powers movies. Yeah... It sure as hell is a random f#cking mix. As usual, I will start with the stuff the game doesn't go right:

First of all, the game only offers a story mode, with 3 humans to select for your main character. That's dissapointing, there's no Freeplay mode, there's no multiplayer, NOTHING. It also only has 2 islands, unlocking the second one midway the story. The lack of content is a real shame, as it could've help make this game stand out and live longer.

The second thing are the bosses. Later on, completely hilariously broken characters with start invading your island. However, this offers a really harsh challenge: You need money to keep your base up, however getting money will get you negative attention. Getting negative attention will make more people go to your island. The more people blowing stuff and killing your minions, the more money you'll need to keep up with everything. Is a never-ending death cycle that will probably end once you're out of the game for good.

The last thing I'll comment uppon is that the game hasn't aged well on performance. There's people who have issues setting the resolution to the game to a number that's actually good for them, and stuff like that.

All of that being said, what's left is a really good strategy game, which also has quite the amounts of comedy.

The biggest standout on this game has to be the designs, animations and graphics. THIS is a great example of cell shaded graphics well put to use. The animations for characters fit perfectly with the cartoony style and FOR F#CK SAKE, THIS GAME HAS THE BEST LOOKING MENUS I'VE SEEN. I'M NOT KIDDING.

Do I recommend this game? If you enjoy strategy games AND like games such as Dungeon Keeper, then I seriously wonder why don't you have it already. It's a really good game, and fun to play. However if you're not a fan of base-managing games, then that might turn your boner off.

TL:DR Edition: Dungeon Keeper mets any Humour-based movie that parodies James Bond and similar stuff. Fun game, although a bit challenging at times. Get it on sale if you like that sort of stuff, totally worth it.

reviewText: Oldie but Goldie. Picked it up relatively late (2015), but it seems to be all the fun it was back when it was released back in 2004. In many ways it reminds of the old James Bond movies, only that you play the villain. Gameplay wise it is a real time strategy, in which you build a lair into a mountain on a remote island. Then you recruit minions, expand your lair, research and upgrade technology, and last but not least deceive or eliminate visitors or enemy agents. You can also run missions in different parts of the world, granting you all sorts of rewards. Evil Genius is actually quite a complex game with many upgrades, research options, traps.. basically lots and lots of options to customize your lair and get expanding/researching. There is no fast forward, which makes sense considering your missions in the world are on a fixed timer, and your minions out there will get killed pretty fast if you don't check in on them occasionally. There are only two maps, although you will spend many, many hours on each of them. It's a slow game, but very rewarding if you take your time.

Ok, this is the real review this time. So, Evil Genuis, a game alot like Mastermind exceot the fact that it cost money and has alot more features and not to mention alot of more time that you will most likely be depositing into this masterpeice.
Have you ever wanted to destroy the world? No? How about take over it? No? How about torture the people that inhabitate it because you can? reviewText:
Originally posted on January 18, 2011

I really want to like Evil Genius. The Bond-villain style of the game is really fun and funny, and the idea of building your island lair up from scratch has some real appeal to it. But in the end this game simply is far too shallow and repetitive to be enjoyable in the long term.

The art design is charming, and so are the animations and sounds, but the meat and potatoes of the gameplay simply loses its appeal far too quickly.

The base building mechanics are solid and the traps are fun to build and use, but there is no differentiation between islands, and you are often restricted in the size of base you can build. Research can grant you more expensive but more space efficient versions of existing technology, but deleting old building plans within the confines of limited space and starting over is a real pain.

The minion AI is atrocious, which I suppose is intentional, but it is also lazy developing. Your minions will constantly die in your own traps, and minions make no distinction between themselves as far as their role goes. Your ever so valuable third tier minions are just as likely to stumble into the gas pit attempting to kill an intruder in hand to hand combat and die as a plain worker is. I don't even want to start talking about how repetitive the evil missions are.

These are just a sampling of the problems with the game. Overall, I would say it is a fun little game that is not worth more than a couple dollars.

reviewText:
Where to begin? I guess with the beginning.  Evil Genius starts with a short FMV giving you the basics of what your about to do.  Build a secret lair in a mountain, perform various Act of Infamy, research various things, and ultimately create your Doomsday Device.  When you start in the game proper you have but a handful of Minions and a single Henchman, your pick of Genius determines which Henchman you get at the start.  I quickly set off and ordered my Minions to build me base, starting with the Corridors and moving on to Barracks, Control Room, and a Mess Hall.

All this base building costs money, and while you do start with a few funds, it’s nowhere near the amount that you’ll need if you plan on creating a Doomsday Device that will bring the Forces of Good to their knees.  For this we have the World Domination Map, where you send your minions off to different regions to steal money or preform Acts of Infamy.

Now here’s where one of my little personal tricks comes into play.  I discovered this about two or three playthroughs ago.  The best way to get the most money right at the start without the heat or agents from the regions getting suspicious of you and investigating your island.  You can do any Acts of Infamy or Stealing, as much as you want, before you complete the mission involving capturing the maid.  No agents will come looking for you until you capture her.  So, I recommend building your Lair as much as you can, and build a massive Barracks full of Lockers(these determine how many Minions you can have).  With enough you can hit your Minion cap and send all of them out to different regions to steal money.  Leave the game running and come back later, I let it run overnight, and you will have a nice pile of gold to get you started.  Just also remember to bring all your Minions back and let it run for a little longer.  Since you will steal acquire Heat, so you want to give some time to let that fade off.

Now is that cheating?  Or is that truly winning at the game and bending the mechanics to better suit your needs?

Now after a few hours you’ll have a pretty nice Lair going for you, probably with some spiffy traps, and plenty of Minions of various types wandering around doing your bidding.  And yes, I do mean hours.  My personal biggest complaint about Evil Genius is it’s lack of game speed control.  There is no way to speed up time in any manor, and so there can be times where you just play to wait.  And that can get boring.

Eventually you’ll make it to the second Island, and this is where the fun really begins.  The is the best part of that game, in my opinion, and really this whole thing is all about my opinion, so therefore, this is the best part of the game!

What do you do first on the second island?  Why build a new Lair of course!  That old island with that old and inferior base that you spent hours getting perfect is now replaced with a new and improved Lair.  You’ve got more space to spread out with and the experience to know how you want to be set up.  But you also have the Forces of Good still being a pain in the ♥♥♥♥, the amount of which is directly proportional to how much of a ruckus you created prior to moving to the new island.

At this point I stop telling you how to play, or what exactly happens when you play.  You have to just go and play it.  Trust me on this.  While you’ll complain at the total number of hours you’ve spent playing it, you’ll know that every minute of that time was spent being the best Evil Genius you could and loving every minute of it.  You may, probably will, get irritated at your Minions from time to time, as the AI does seem to just slip here and there.  But overall it’s never anything truly gamebreaking, and these time are sparse enough that you wont even remember all of them.

You can really push yourself, and your own morals, as to what it takes to be an Evil Genius.  Does it end with beating the game?  Or is it more than that?  After all, almost all the game files are written in Excel spreadsheets, and can altered in any way you choose.  A quick Google search will result with a list of in game cheatcodes.  Is using these cheating?  Is altering the games core files to better your success cheating?  These types of actions could be considered being nefarious, something which the game itself rewards you for being.

The graphics and stylized look of Evil Genius both seem to have held on well with the times.  While you can tell it’s a dated game, its not so blinding obvious.  The music too is a perfect fit for it’s visual look.

I have only three real complaints about Evil Genius.  One you cannot effect the passing of time, two you cannot zoom out far enough, to my personal liking, and three I had to fix the resolution every time I started the game.  But hey, if that’s my only compatibility issue, I’ll live.

reviewText:
I don't know any other games that embrace the Spy genre with this much style. Everything about this game, from the music to the characters, is meant to fully immerse you into a world of minions and doomsday devices.

The concept is simple. You are an average Bond villain, and you want to take over the world. In order to do so you need a base of operations (which you have to lay out and build yourself), an army of minions (who live in your base and are trained into better jobs there) and a control room that lets you send your minions across the globe to steal money for you and carry out devious schemes. But this attracts the attention of the 5 superpowers in the world, who will start sending investigators and agents to your base. As your global notoriety climbs, you have to manage your heat or you will become overwhelmed by the number of investigators and soldiers sent to  attack your base.

The game is an incredible lot of fun to play. Although your first base design will inevitably suck, the more you play the better you will get at it. (Also, a minor spoiler: halfway through the game you move to a new base, which lets you fix any mistakes you may have made that playthrough... Only to make a bunch of new ones, of course.)

But I also have two gripes. First of all, you can issue basic orders and give anyone on your island a tag that determines what must be done with them (jailed, dazed or killed), but you cannot directly control your minions. This is understandable - you ARE the mastermind, after all - but can get quite frustrating when all of your minions are busy and you really need something done. Fortunately you can directly control your henchmen, who may not be able to build or do much work around your base, but who are very good at killing, dazing or jailing intruders.

Second of all... The game has a lot of bugs, and most of them are really minor and solved by the Unofficial Patch. Why no such patch was ever brought out officially is beyond me. There are also game breaking bugs: for example, once you place down the conference table in the first island, you may not move or delete it or your evil genius can no longer sit at it. This, of course, halts progression and gets you stuck.

Fortunately these two problems are not extremely big, and have not ruined my fun yet. It's good to be an Evil Genius.

reviewText:
Where to begin? I guess with the beginning.  Evil Genius starts with a short FMV giving you the basics of what your about to do.  Build a secret lair in a mountain, perform various Act of Infamy, research various things, and ultimately create your Doomsday Device.  When you start in the game proper you have but a handful of Minions and a single Henchman, your pick of Genius determines which Henchman you get at the start.  I quickly set off and ordered my Minions to build me base, starting with the Corridors and moving on to Barracks, Control Room, and a Mess Hall.

All this base building costs money, and while you do start with a few funds, it’s nowhere near the amount that you’ll need if you plan on creating a Doomsday Device that will bring the Forces of Good to their knees.  For this we have the World Domination Map, where you send your minions off to different regions to steal money or preform Acts of Infamy.

Now here’s where one of my little personal tricks comes into play.  I discovered this about two or three playthroughs ago.  The best way to get the most money right at the start without the heat or agents from the regions getting suspicious of you and investigating your island.  You can do any Acts of Infamy or Stealing, as much as you want, before you complete the mission involving capturing the maid.  No agents will come looking for you until you capture her.  So, I recommend building your Lair as much as you can, and build a massive Barracks full of Lockers(these determine how many Minions you can have).  With enough you can hit your Minion cap and send all of them out to different regions to steal money.  Leave the game running and come back later, I let it run overnight, and you will have a nice pile of gold to get you started.  Just also remember to bring all your Minions back and let it run for a little longer.  Since you will steal acquire Heat, so you want to give some time to let that fade off.

Now is that cheating?  Or is that truly winning at the game and bending the mechanics to better suit your needs?

Now after a few hours you’ll have a pretty nice Lair going for you, probably with some spiffy traps, and plenty of Minions of various types wandering around doing your bidding.  And yes, I do mean hours.  My personal biggest complaint about Evil Genius is it’s lack of game speed control.  There is no way to speed up time in any manor, and so there can be times where you just play to wait.  And that can get boring.

Eventually you’ll make it to the second Island, and this is where the fun really begins.  The is the best part of that game, in my opinion, and really this whole thing is all about my opinion, so therefore, this is the best part of the game!

What do you do first on the second island?  Why build a new Lair of course!  That old island with that old and inferior base that you spent hours getting perfect is now replaced with a new and improved Lair.  You’ve got more space to spread out with and the experience to know how you want to be set up.  But you also have the Forces of Good still being a pain in the ♥♥♥♥, the amount of which is directly proportional to how much of a ruckus you created prior to moving to the new island.

At this point I stop telling you how to play, or what exactly happens when you play.  You have to just go and play it.  Trust me on this.  While you’ll complain at the total number of hours you’ve spent playing it, you’ll know that every minute of that time was spent being the best Evil Genius you could and loving every minute of it.  You may, probably will, get irritated at your Minions from time to time, as the AI does seem to just slip here and there.  But overall it’s never anything truly gamebreaking, and these time are sparse enough that you wont even remember all of them.

You can really push yourself, and your own morals, as to what it takes to be an Evil Genius.  Does it end with beating the game?  Or is it more than that?  After all, almost all the game files are written in Excel spreadsheets, and can altered in any way you choose.  A quick Google search will result with a list of in game cheatcodes.  Is using these cheating?  Is altering the games core files to better your success cheating?  These types of actions could be considered being nefarious, something which the game itself rewards you for being.

The graphics and stylized look of Evil Genius both seem to have held on well with the times.  While you can tell it’s a dated game, its not so blinding obvious.  The music too is a perfect fit for it’s visual look.

I have only three real complaints about Evil Genius.  One you cannot effect the passing of time, two you cannot zoom out far enough, to my personal liking, and three I had to fix the resolution every time I started the game.  But hey, if that’s my only compatibility issue, I’ll live.

This game mixes base building perfectly with solid retrospective humour. Those of you familiar with old James Bond movies, with feel right at home with this games comedic foundations. The game will have you developing traps that open the floor to a deadly pit of saws one minute and then have you interrogating a prisioner with Micheal Jackson choreography the next.

The game oozes with charm. Not only that, but the game offers a solid strategic challenge as well. You will find yourself having to keep track of both your base activies and your world domition tactics on the world map (Think total war, but with everything happening at once). This sense of micro-management will never leave you bored, or unatentive. The game always presents a obstacle for you to overcome, rather that be enemy agents trying to inflitrate your base, a power failure leaving your base vunerable or trying to keep pesky tourists from wondering into your evil lair the game consistently presents you with challenges, some difficult some not, and never at any point leaves you with nothing to do.

Overall, this game is ranked in my Steam favourites. The game is genuinly funny and light hearted. It presents challenge with its gameplay, has a addictive formula to boot and is a hit for those who are fans of games like Dungeon(s) Keeper, Tropico and the like.

It's not straightforward to recommend this game. On the gameplay front it does many things poorly, several in game factors collaborate to frustrate the player. Stupid minions running one by one into their deaths, while you can only watch their folly. Pesky invulnerable super agents destroying your base. Traps being somewhat poorly balanced. There's no way to turn off just the announcer's warnings - you'd have to turn off all sounds. The pacing is very slow at the beginning. There are only two islands on which to construct your bases - no random maps, no skirmish mode. Specialist science minions and social minions have little to do. Acts of infamy provide little tangible benefit...

How can the game be any good then?
Because of the things it does good, it does really well. And there are very few games similar to this (Dungeon Keeper being the closest).
It's all style over substance. The art direction, themes and music (particularly title soundtracks) are just spot on and so perfectly captures the idea of playing Bond-film like villain, constructing a secret base in order to take over the world! The animations are superbly done, cartoony, but appropriately so. Thus even though the game is 10 years old, it still manages to look alright.

I don't know any other games that embrace the Spy genre with this much style. Everything about this game, from the music to the characters, is meant to fully immerse you into a world of minions and doomsday devices.

The concept is simple. You are an average Bond villain, and you want to take over the world. In order to do so you need a base of operations (which you have to lay out and build yourself), an army of minions (who live in your base and are trained into better jobs there) and a control room that lets you send your minions across the globe to steal money for you and carry out devious schemes. But this attracts the attention of the 5 superpowers in the world, who will start sending investigators and agents to your base. As your global notoriety climbs, you have to manage your heat or you will become overwhelmed by the number of investigators and soldiers sent to  attack your base.

The game is an incredible lot of fun to play. Although your first base design will inevitably suck, the more you play the better you will get at it. (Also, a minor spoiler: halfway through the game you move to a new base, which lets you fix any mistakes you may have made that playthrough... Only to make a bunch of new ones, of course.)

But I also have two gripes. First of all, you can issue basic orders and give anyone on your island a tag that determines what must be done with them (jailed, dazed or killed), but you cannot directly control your minions. This is understandable - you ARE the mastermind, after all - but can get quite frustrating when all of your minions are busy and you really need something done. Fortunately you can directly control your henchmen, who may not be able to build or do much work around your base, but who are very good at killing, dazing or jailing intruders.

Second of all... The game has a lot of bugs, and most of them are really minor and solved by the Unofficial Patch. Why no such patch was ever brought out officially is beyond me. There are also game breaking bugs: for example, once you place down the conference table in the first island, you may not move or delete it or your evil genius can no longer sit at it. This, of course, halts progression and gets you stuck.

Fortunately these two problems are not extremely big, and have not ruined my fun yet. It's good to be an Evil Genius.

Those who have played this gem of a game, know exactly what to expect.  This game is still great to play and I still highly recommend it after all this time.  The game is basically a port over to steam, but nothing has notably changed or been altered (possibly better sound) but since it is an older game, you may find it outdated, but as it has a cartoon style, there is not much to complain about (both graphical and controll aspect)...

But for those who do not know much about the game, here are the basic reason(s) to become the next Evil Genius...

Basically this is a building / stratagy simulation game where you play the leader of an evil organization controlling various minion types with the main goal of trying to take over the world... while building your evil base, you must keep your base productive, keep your minions happy, while also defending it from the various, government agents, tourists and wild life...

It may start off a little lack luster as you start constructing your base, but you will eventually find the game moves alot faster after various goals have been achieved, obtaining a higher notority level and having more objects to build within the various rooms.

There are many unique features that makes Evil Genius stand out amongst others, but personally, there are 3 key fatures make it stand out most from this genre...

The first thing is the ability to evolove your minions, where as most sim's or stratagy type games are designed with purchusing various unity to help, Evil Genius relies on promoting your minions through training them.  These upgraded minions branch out to become better soldiers, engineers, valets, etc. with each of these upgrades having their own branching upgrades.  For example, soldiers can be trained to become either a sniper specialist, mercenary, etc.  Each minion has a unique name, with various levels (health, loyalty, inteligence, hunger, etc.)  making each minion feel a little more personal, unique, and harder to send out into the world, not knowing who and who will not be retuning from the mission (poor bobby johnson did not see that cliff in front of him :( )... but if your minions become disloyal and try and steal or try to desert your organization, you have plenty of options to show them their wrongdoing... try capturing and interogate them with your interogation chair, or cake mixer, or laser cutter, or whatever as you watch them squirm... or simply get your henchmen to do the dirty work by beating them comedically, or simply locking them up and useing them as experimental test subjects for your scientists.

As the Evil Genius is the main unit, there is always a #2 unit, and this will be your main henchman.  Unlike the traditional unit, he will respond to identified threats immediatly and will protect you until the last unit of health with 3 special / unique abilities to help eliminate mass groups of enemies.  Each henchman has there own special backstory and with more henchmen becoming availiable to you as the plot progresses.

The second thing is the global map with the various prizes that can be obtained (in some missions).  This global map is how you the 'Evil Genius' obtains notority.  Each mission provides a humourous debriefing, requiring a specified number of minions and alotted survival time in order to succeed in the mission.   Once completed, you gain notority and In some cases are reward with a physical trophy that can be placed within your lair.  As you gain more notroity, more missions will become availiable, in some cases, missions become availiable only when minions are sent to the specific country on recon.  The trophies obtained provide various effects and in some cases are cursed until all compontents are obtained and combined to create a larger / completed trophy.  Like any evil genius, you have to have that trophy room to look at all of your evil loot...

The third and final thing, is you as the evil genius... or at least the one you control in the game.  The Evil Genius is the leader / controller of the units, there are 3 leaders to choose at the start of your game, each one providing different benefits during your main game.  This may mean more loyalty, more stength, faster recon on the global map, etc.  As mentioned earlier with minion loyalty, As the game progresses, your Evil Genius may be required to show your followers who is top dog via torturing or straight out exacuting a minion in front of other minioins to raise the moral level.  Again, these acts done in a more humorus manner (an 'Austin Powers' type death).  When called upon, your Evil Genius CLONE.... I mean REAL Evil Genius may have to particiapte in missions to successfully complete them.

If you like this type of game, and want to experience the James Bond nostaligia with that Austin Powers sense of humor then I hightly recommend this game.  Go forth, become the Evil Genius you always wanted to be and RULE THIS FICTIONAL WORLD!

reviewText:
I missed this game when it first released but had always wanted to give it a go as I heard it was similar to Dungeon Keeper, a much loved game from my early PC gaming days. After seeing it had launched on Steam for a modest price I snagged a copy and am pleasantly surprised by how in depth this hidden gem is, in some ways I actually prefer it to Dungeon Keeper.

The interesting thing about this villainous base builder is that rather than building small lairs and moving from level to level, you only have two islands to build on, one that you access from the start and another that unlocks halfway through. This allows you to expand your HQ over time and it's a rewarding experience to finally see your underground criminal empire begin to flourish. You also have access to a world map screen that allows you to influence the world outside of your base by sending your henchmen to commit crimes or perform espionage in various countries which brings in gold, specialist units and ups your notoriety. But beware, the more influential you become, the more secret agents the governments of the world will send to your island to unravel your insidious schemes. It should be noted that the game's theme is heavily influenced by 60s spy serials and it carries this off with a comedic tone reminiscent of the Austin Powers movies, which I rather enjoyed.

If you're a fan of Dungeon Keeper or looking to get into to the whole base building, overlord style strategy genre, I highly recommend this game. It's a great time sink and it's easy to lose a few hours twiddling your evil moustache and plotting world domination. Just be sure to watch out for that pesky super agent John Steele.

Those who have played this gem of a game, know exactly what to expect.  This game is still great to play and I still highly recommend it after all this time.  The game is basically a port over to steam, but nothing has notably changed or been altered (possibly better sound) but since it is an older game, you may find it outdated, but as it has a cartoon style, there is not much to complain about (both graphical and controll aspect)...

But for those who do not know much about the game, here are the basic reason(s) to become the next Evil Genius...

Basically this is a building / stratagy simulation game where you play the leader of an evil organization controlling various minion types with the main goal of trying to take over the world... while building your evil base, you must keep your base productive, keep your minions happy, while also defending it from the various, government agents, tourists and wild life...

It may start off a little lack luster as you start constructing your base, but you will eventually find the game moves alot faster after various goals have been achieved, obtaining a higher notority level and having more objects to build within the various rooms.

There are many unique features that makes Evil Genius stand out amongst others, but personally, there are 3 key fatures make it stand out most from this genre...

The first thing is the ability to evolove your minions, where as most sim's or stratagy type games are designed with purchusing various unity to help, Evil Genius relies on promoting your minions through training them.  These upgraded minions branch out to become better soldiers, engineers, valets, etc. with each of these upgrades having their own branching upgrades.  For example, soldiers can be trained to become either a sniper specialist, mercenary, etc.  Each minion has a unique name, with various levels (health, loyalty, inteligence, hunger, etc.)  making each minion feel a little more personal, unique, and harder to send out into the world, not knowing who and who will not be retuning from the mission (poor bobby johnson did not see that cliff in front of him :( )... but if your minions become disloyal and try and steal or try to desert your organization, you have plenty of options to show them their wrongdoing... try capturing and interogate them with your interogation chair, or cake mixer, or laser cutter, or whatever as you watch them squirm... or simply get your henchmen to do the dirty work by beating them comedically, or simply locking them up and useing them as experimental test subjects for your scientists.

As the Evil Genius is the main unit, there is always a #2 unit, and this will be your main henchman.  Unlike the traditional unit, he will respond to identified threats immediatly and will protect you until the last unit of health with 3 special / unique abilities to help eliminate mass groups of enemies.  Each henchman has there own special backstory and with more henchmen becoming availiable to you as the plot progresses.

The second thing is the global map with the various prizes that can be obtained (in some missions).  This global map is how you the 'Evil Genius' obtains notority.  Each mission provides a humourous debriefing, requiring a specified number of minions and alotted survival time in order to succeed in the mission.   Once completed, you gain notority and In some cases are reward with a physical trophy that can be placed within your lair.  As you gain more notroity, more missions will become availiable, in some cases, missions become availiable only when minions are sent to the specific country on recon.  The trophies obtained provide various effects and in some cases are cursed until all compontents are obtained and combined to create a larger / completed trophy.  Like any evil genius, you have to have that trophy room to look at all of your evil loot...

The third and final thing, is you as the evil genius... or at least the one you control in the game.  The Evil Genius is the leader / controller of the units, there are 3 leaders to choose at the start of your game, each one providing different benefits during your main game.  This may mean more loyalty, more stength, faster recon on the global map, etc.  As mentioned earlier with minion loyalty, As the game progresses, your Evil Genius may be required to show your followers who is top dog via torturing or straight out exacuting a minion in front of other minioins to raise the moral level.  Again, these acts done in a more humorus manner (an 'Austin Powers' type death).  When called upon, your Evil Genius CLONE.... I mean REAL Evil Genius may have to particiapte in missions to successfully complete them.

If you like this type of game, and want to experience the James Bond nostaligia with that Austin Powers sense of humor then I hightly recommend this game.  Go forth, become the Evil Genius you always wanted to be and RULE THIS FICTIONAL WORLD!

What I liked about the game:
1. I loved the satirical elements that mocked spies specifically from spy movies.

What I disliked about the game:
1. A tad slow at times where you are trying to generate cash, sometimes you are brainlessly checking to make sure no agents get into the inner part of your base.

4. I would recommend it to any person who has seen a couple spy movies to appreciate the satire.

1. Patience is needed when playing this game. (World Domination isn't as easy as clicking your mouse once)

Overall, I would recommend this game. If you don't think you would like it, give it a try!

reviewText: I love the slightly retro, over the top villaniny portrayed in this charming game. My only criticism come from a lack of camera control and some out-dated mechanics. Other than that this game is fantastic. I thouroughly reccomend it.

First off:

BE CAREFUL WHERE YOU PLACE YOUR CONFERENCE TABLE

If you move or delete it at any point after building it but before Objective 2 is totally complete, you'll glitch your savegame and be unable to proceed.

That being said, this game is phenomenal.  Pretty forgiving early on, with a difficulty arc both graceful and satisfying that really gets much tougher later.  The graphics are of course dated, but as is the hallmark of many truly great games it doesn't matter.  The fun comes from the game, and the graphics are there to help you keep track.

It is often compared to the Dungeoun Keeper series, which is fair.  I played me some Dungeon Keeper 2 back in the day, when mice had balls and input devices were not even hot-swappable, let alone wireless.  Despite the relative technological desolation of those dark ages, I remember that being a pretty awesome game.  Still, I cannot adequately describe how much happier I am to be a sinister plotting megalomaniac bent on world domination.

Many of the reviews here already break the game down by pros and cons, etc, so I'm just going to say highly recommended, and even when not on sale it's pretty cheap.  Take a spiritual journey to 2004 with Elixir Studios and get in touch with your inner despicable villian.

Extra Endorsement: I experienced the glitch with the conference table on my very first playthrough of the game, and found out about it on the internet after being stuck for hours unable to complete Objective 2.  20ish hours into the game, my whole save became worthless.  Without any hesitation, I calmly opened the menu and clicked New Game".  For me
date: that means this game = digital crack."
